_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Wilson Fertilizer Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:



This facility is a wholesale farm supply distribution center.  We store and distribute a wide variety of pesticides and fertilizers, including Aqueous Ammonia.  We are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of these products at our facility.  It is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling aqueous ammonia to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as our co-workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby businesses and members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Local, State, and Federal rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle aqueous ammonia, combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility.  This is culminated in the safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.



The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38; has provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA); has coordinated to the best of the abilities of Wilson Fertilizer Management response actions with the Local Fire Departments, including pre-emergency planning and emergency training; attempts to verify annually that the County Emergency Plan includes the facility in the event of a release of regulated substances; and, has instructed employees on procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Aqueous Ammonia is received by truck and is stored in bulk and portable tanks.  This facility has equipment for unloading transports and equipment to load semis.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel, customers, an

d authorized contractors.



Worst Case Scenario



The worst case scenario would be the release of all contents of the largest container over a 10 minute time frame.



According to RMP Comp modeling, this release (distance from point of dispersion to 200 ppm) would have off-site consequences



Alternate Case Scenario



According to RMP Comp modeling, this release (distance from point of dispersion to 200 ppm) would not have significant off-site consequences.



 

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps



This distribution facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  Periodic inspections by the Office of the Indiana State Chemist are also conducted.  Employees involved in aqueous ammonia activities are trained thoroughly by the Management Team, contractor(s), insurance company representatives, and industry experts.  Competency is measured through written and oral testing, demonstration (hands-on), and observations.



The major hazards identified with aqueous ammonia include toxic release, overfilling, equipment failure, earthquakes, and tornado.



Check valves and manual shutoff valves are utilized to minimize the potential for release.



Maintenance programs are also in place.  Items are replaced if they fail, present a risk to the user, are required by law or standard, are out-of-date, or if a system or process is changed or upgraded.  The Office of the Indiana State Chemist also makes periodic unannounced visits to our facility to inspect equipment, tanks, and safety training (they do not always leave documentation).  In addition, employees utilizing the equipment on a near daily basis informally inspect the equipment for leaks, cracks, soundness, etc.



5 Year Accident History



There have not been any reportable or investigated incidents at this facility



Emergency Response Program



This facility has an emergency action plan, in accor

dance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38.  We have coordinated response actions with the local fire department, including pre-emergency planning and emergency training.  We have discussed this program with the County Local Emergency Planning Committee, and our facility is included in the County Emergency Plan.  In the event of a release of regulated substances, our employees have been instructed on the procedures for notification of the local fire authority, Goodland Fire Department, emergency personnel, and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



At this facility, safety improvement is an ongoing process.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  This facility is in compliance with the Office of the Indiana State Chemist Ammonia Laws and Regulations.  Updates and improvement are occurring as technology and equipment becomes available.
